qualifications: Must be enrolled in or have completed a computer science degree, or equivalent. Must meet the qualifications to TA *ALL* of CSC 108, 148, and 165 (see CSC108H1-B, CSC148H1, CSC165H1 qualifications). Enthusiasm and patience for face-to-face teaching of beginners is required. Experience with CSC 104 or Racket preferred.
duties: Hold office hours on a weekly basis to assist students taking 100-level CSC courses.

qualifications: Must be enrolled in, or have completed, an undergraduate program in computer science or education (or equivalent). Demonstrated excellent English communication skills. Patience teaching technical concepts to students with a wide variety of non-technical backgrounds. Must have completed or be in the process of completing a course involving functional programming. Must be able to write code in the Intermediate Student Language of Racket, and trace it in the same manner as the Intermediate Student Language Stepper of the DrRacket development environment.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Demonstrated excellent English communication skills. Demonstrated excellent organizational skills. Experience with Python, at the level of CSC148 or equivalent. At least one year of prior TA experience in first year courses is required, experience with CSC108 is preferred. Graduate applicants preferred.
duties: Assist course coordinator with TA management and course administration. Hold marking meetings on Friday afternoons. Mentor and provide feedback to other TAs.

qualifications: Experience with programming, such as by completing a 200-level CSC course, or by achieving excellent marks in multiple 100-level CSC courses, or equivalent. Experience with Python, at the level of CSC 148 or equivalent. Must be enrolled in or have completed a computer science degree, or equivalent. Must be interested in teaching beginner programmers. Willing to try different approaches when explaining simple concepts. TAs should be available during at least one of the CSC 108 lecture times (MWF10-11, W6-9).
duties: Attend lectures to assist in classroom activities. Prepare for each week by doing online programming activities. Some TAs may hold office hours or monitor discussion forums.

qualifications: Experience with programming, such as by completing a 200-level CSC course, or by achieving excellent marks in multiple 100-level CSC courses, or equivalent. Experience with Python, at the level of CSC 148 or equivalent. Must be enrolled in or have completed a computer science degree, or equivalent.
duties: Assignment marking meetings will be held on Friday afternoons. Perform semi-regular marking tasks that require prompt turnaround. TAs may be required to attend lectures or hold office hours.

qualifications: Experience programming in Python, exceptional marks in CSC108/CSC148. Interest in teaching beginners. Excellent communication skills. Familiarity with the UTM computing environment. Previous experience as a teaching assistant in CS an asset.
Experience writing programs in R. Interest in teaching beginning programmers.
duties: Marking programming assignments written in R. One-on-one tutoring of students doing R programming exercises in a computer lab.

qualifications: Must be enrolled in, or have completed, an undergraduate program in Computer Science, including CSC148 or equivalent. Must have strong knowledge of basic data structures (stacks, queues, linked lists, binary search trees), recursion, object-oriented programming in Python, and introductory complexity. Experience with a debugger, unit testing, and interest in face-to-face teaching an asset. If you are interested in a Head TA position, in addition to this online application please email Tracy Wu <tracywu@cs.toronto.edu> with your resume and a statement of interest. Additional qualifications for Head TA include excellent organizational skills, strong communication skills, strong UNIX skills, and strong skills for software testing and for writing and running scripts.
duties: Grading assignments and exams. Leading weekly labs and attending TA meetings. Possibly holding office hours or monitoring the online discussion board.

qualifications: Knowledge of Python, program testing, data structures, introductory complexity, and object-oriented design. Excellent communication skills. Familiarity with the UTM computing environment.
duties: Grading assignments and exams. Leading weekly labs and attending TA meetings. Possibly holding office hours or monitoring the online discussion board.

qualifications: Must be enrolled in, or have completed, an undergraduate program in computer science or mathematics (or equivalent). Demonstrated excellent communication skills. Willing to try different approaches when explaining simple concepts. Familiar with the Python programming language (we connect logic and coding). Demonstrated experience with predicate and propositional logic, and the formal definitions of asymptotic bounds. Must be able to grade proofs, including ones describing the asymptotic behaviour of code. If you are interested in a CSC165H Head TA position, please apply to TA CSC165H and also email Tracy Wu (tracywu@cs.toronto.edu) to inform her of your interest. Additional requirements for Head TA: excellent organizational skills;strong communication skills.
duties: TA duties may include: marking student work, leading tutorial meetings, leading Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions.

qualifications: Strong knowledge of Java, principles of object?oriented program design, design patterns. Experience with software design using CRC cards or equivalent. Experience using current Software Engineering best practices (including code reviews, unit testing, TDD, and version control - svn or git preferred), such as by completing CSC301 or having professional programming experience. Ability to provide supervision for student development teams. Knowledge of Android programming. Enthusiasm for teaching. Must already have, or be enrolled in, a computer science degree (or equivalent). If you are interested in a CSC207 Head TA position, please apply to TA CSC207 and also email Paul Gries (pgries@cs.utoronto.ca). Additional requirements for Head TA: Excellent organizational skills. Strong communication skills. Ability to write and run scripts. Strong UNIX skills.
duties: A subset of the following: Leading weekly labs and attending TA meetings. Attending lectures to help with inverted activities. Grading assignments and tests. Holding office hours. Invigilating tests. Monitoring the online discussion board. One-on-one tutoring of students working on programming exercises. Proofreading course materials.

qualifications: Must have completed or be in the process of completing CSC369 (operating systems) or equivalent. Must be able to write C code involving system calls including fork, wait, pipe, select, sigaction. Experience with gdb. TAs should be available during CSC 209 lecture times (MW 10-11, 12-1) for some weeks of flipped-classroom activities.
duties: Giving brief lab demos, helping students during lab periods and lecture periods, grading assignments and tests, holding infrequent office hours.

qualifications: Extensive experience with C, *nix and *nix tools. Excellent communication skills.
duties: Grading assignments and exams. Running weekly office hours and supporting weekly labs.

qualifications: Thorough familiarity with mathematical induction and some of its applications to computer science (particularly for correctness proofs of iterative and recursive algorithms) and through knowledge of automata theory, and the theory of regular and context-free languages. Must be enrolled in, or have completed, an undergraduate program in Computer Science, including CSC236 or equivalent. Desirable: Experience grading proofs.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Strong theoretical background, excellent communication skills, thorough understanding of mathematical induction and its application to analyzing and proving the correctness of recursive and iterative algorithms, knowledge of the theory of regular languages, ability to carefully grade proofs.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Must have hands?on experience with digital integrated circuits, and a past grade of A- or higher from CSC258 or an equivalent course. Preference will be given to applicants with past experience with Verilog and microcontrollers, who have or are working toward an undergraduate degree in Computer Science or Engineering.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Knowledge of computer organization, introductory logic design, and assembly language programming. Familiarity with the UTM computing environment required. Interest in FPGA programming desirable. Experience in Verilog is a plus.

Excellent knowledge of algorithms and data structures, as evidenced by having taken and excelled in a course on this topic. Experience and ability to carefully grade correctness and complexity proofs of algorithms and data structures. Must have mastered: (1) common data structures including priority queues (such as heaps), dictionaries (such as balanced search trees and hash tables), disjoint sets;(2) basic graph algorithms, e.g., graph searches and minimum spanning tree constructions;and (3) techniques for complexity analysis, including worst?case, average case, and amortized.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Required: Must have taken this course or similar one. Strong writing skills. Desired: Knowledge of current events related to technology. Experience with facilitating group discussions. Video creation or editing experience is a plus.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Solid background in Computer Science;Skilled and enthusiastic user of software development tools. For instance, can coach students on how to setup a Java IDE to pull code from git repo and run Junit tests, or refactor code, or examine a git branch. Experienced OO programmer, with firsthand knowledge of design patterns, code refactoring, good sense for software architecture. Working knowledge of Agile processes (eg Scrum or XP);Understanding of release management. (How features find their way to release branches). Hands-on experience with modern libraries and frameworks, web development, git, issue tracking tools;excellent communication skills, ability to supervise student development teams;Enthusiasm for teaching.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Experience in large software development projects;familiarity with traditional software engineering methods and current agile, XP methods;software engineering tools, version control, and UML.

Solid background in Computer Science;Skilled and enthusiastic user of software development tools. For instance, can coach students on how to setup a Java IDE to pull code from git repo and run Junit tests, or refactor code, or examine a git branch. Experienced OO programmer, with firsthand knowledge of design patterns, code refactoring, good sense for software architecture. Working knowledge of Agile processes (eg Scrum or XP);Understanding of release management. (How features find their way to release branches). Hands-on experience with modern libraries and frameworks, web development, git, issue tracking tools;excellent communication skills, ability to supervise student development teams;Enthusiasm for teaching.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Experience building web applications. Experience with HTML5, CSS3, JavaScript, AJAX and git. Candidates who have experience with NodeJS, or a major web framework such as Django or Rails are preferred.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: XHTML, PHP, Javascript, Jquery, SQL, experience with web frameworks, mobile development.

Significant experience with HCI and user-centered user interface design/evaluation;one or more HCI or user-centered design courses: the candidate should have already completed CSC318 or an equivalent HCI course. Candidates with completed undergraduate degrees in CS or related discipline are strongly preferred. Desirable: Experience with user interface prototyping tools.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Background and interest in computer vision, as evidenced by having taken CSC2503 (or another grad vision course with essentially the same content) and passed it with a grade of A- or higher. Knowledge of C++ and Python is required. Knowledge of OpenCV, and of programming on iOS and/or Android is a plus but is not strictly necessary.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Experience and interest in machine learning and neural networks, as evidenced by work in the area and/or excellent performance in university courses in machine learning and neural networks. Thorough understanding of the fundamentals of machine learning and neural networks, including a thorough understanding of the mathematical and computational techniques used in CSC321, such as gradient descent and eigendecomposition of matrices. Familiarity with deep learning. Ability to communicate complex ideas clearly. Excellent programming skills;extensive experience working in a scientific computing framework such as SciPy/NumPy or MATLAB;familiarity with Python.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Experience with functional and logic programming paradigms. Experience with Racket (or Scheme or Lisp), Prolog, and Haskell. Desirable: Scheme macros, knowledge of functors and monads.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: knowledge of computer arithmetic error analysis, conditioning and stability, Gauss elimination, pivoting, banded and sparse matrices, operation counts, norms, Newtons method, convergence analysis, polynomial and spline interpolation, good knowledge of MATLAB.
duties: Marking assignments and/or exams;possibly offering some tutorials.

qualifications: Matlab and/or numerical programming in Python, numerical methods, linear algebra, calculus.

Must be enrolled in, or have completed, an undergraduate program in Computer Science or equivalent. Must have completed CSC343 (introduction to databases) or equivalent. Strong knowledge of SQL, relational algebra, and relational design theory (functional dependencies, normal forms etc). Desired:Java and JDBC;experience with map reduce or big data analytics.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Academic or engineering experience with networks -- Familiarity with network concepts including protocols, hardware, routing, addressing, and congestion control. Previous experience with socket programming and Python, as well as knowledge of statistics, required.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Familiarity with network concepts including protocols, hardware, routing, addressing, and congestion control. Previous experience with socket programming and Python required. Familiarity with the UTM computing environment preferred. Familiarity with Mininet.

Knowledge of computability theory (Turing machines, Church's thesis, computable and non-computable functions, many-one reducibility) and complexity theory (P, NP, polynomial-time reducibility, NP-completeness, PSPACE) -- such as from taking this course or equivalent (e.g., CSC 364, 366, 438). Experience grading proofs.
Extensive experience in C;knowledge of concurrency;familiarity with Unix/Linux;able user of version control, debuggers, compilers;good mark in this course or similar OS course.
duties: Leading tutorials, grading assignments and tests. Some TAs may be asked to help develop automated tests for assignments, test questions or additional tutorial material.

qualifications: Demonstrated familiarity with standard algorithm design techniques (greedy strategies, dynamic programming, network flow and linear programming) and with the theory of NP-completeness. Experience marking proofs of correctness and complexity analysis of algorithms, as well as reductions for NP-completeness.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Must be in or have completed the senior year of an undergraduate degree in computer science, mathematics or a comparable discipline. Must have taken an introductory course in Artificial Intelligence, comparable to CSC384, and received a mark of at least 80%. Several of the course assignments require programming in the python programming language. As such, familiarity with python is preferred. Good communication skills and a passion for AI are assets.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Python, Unix;statistics;knowledge of or experience with course material. Desirable: Matlab
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Interest and preferably experience in game design. Must already have or be in the senior year of an undergraduate degree in computer science (or equivalent). Must have knowledge of tools relevant to game design such as Unity (preferably), Blender, OpenGL, or XNA.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Experience and interest in machine learning, as evidenced by research work in the area and/or excellent performance in university courses in machine learning and neural networks such as CSC411/2515. Thorough understanding of the fundamentals of machine learning, including a thorough understanding of the fundamental mathematical and computational techniques used in CSC411, such as gradient descent, eigendecomposition of matrices, and basic probability theory. Experience with deep learning and/or reinforcement learning preferred. Ability to communicate complex ideas clearly. Excellent programming skills;extensive experience working in a scientific computing framework such as SciPy/NumPy or MATLAB;familiarity with Python.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Working knowledge of Python required, and strong background in linear algebra, probability and statistics. Focus on/background in machine learning and probabilistic graphical models preferred. Must be able to grade homework involving deriving inference and learning algorithms.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: C++, Linux, OpenGL, linear algebra, and experience with interactive computer graphics and raytracing. Experience with both Mac and Windows is ideal.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Advanced knowledge of computer vision, with an emphasis on image understanding and neural networks. Excellent background in vision Matlab programming and good knowledge of Python.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: A good understanding of digital forensic methodologies, including the chain of custody, digital evidence collection, analysis and report writing. Experience with various digital forensic tools such as Encase, IEF and Autopsy. Certifications in the field of digital forensics are a bonus. Proven presentation and instructional skills.

Graduate level background in HCI;must have taken CSC428/2514 or equivalent (CSC318 not sufficient);thorough understanding of experimental design, data analysis, and inferential statistics;demonstrated experience marking essays/term papers. Desirable: Experience in design, conduct, and analysis of HCI experiments.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Thorough knowledge of theory and implementation of databases: A or higher in graduate level DB course (such as CSC2509/2525/2531) and equivalent of A- or higher in advanced OS course (such as CSC469/2208). Desirable: C/C++ and Java.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Good background in numerical analysis;knowledge of finite difference and finite element discretization methods for PDEs;Matlab. Desirable: Knowledge of advanced methods for PDEs;good mark in CSC446/2310 or a similar course.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Must be very familiar with the software industry in general (i.e. major sectors and segments, key players, structure, economics, etc.);Business and revenue models and modelling for software enterprises;Software production, distribution, marketing, promotion, and sales methods, models, and strategies;Financial forecasting, analysis, and reporting;Developing, validating, and presenting business plans;Software entrepreneurship (i.e. start-up methods and practices, partnership strategies, raising financial capital, etc.) Candidates must also possess strong team facilitation, coaching, and mentoring skills, including conflict management skills;Hands-on experience in the software industry, ideally within entrepreneurial software ventures.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Knowledge of computability theory (Turing machines, Churchs thesis, computable and non-computable functions, many-one reducibility) and complexity theory (P, NP, polynomial-time reducibility, NP-completeness, PSPACE) -- such as from taking this course or equivalent (e.g., CSC 364, 366, 438). Experience grading proofs.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: A solid understanding of algorithm design and analysis, as demonstrated by having taken and excelled in a course on the topic. Must be familiar with basic algorithm design techniques (divide and conquer, greedy, dynamic programming, network flows, linear programming), as well as with more advanced topics such as probabilistic analysis, the primal-dual framework, approximation algorithms and online algorithms. Experience marking proofs of correctness and complexity analysis of algorithms is necessary.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Demonstrated research interest in this area. Pursuing a graduate degree in Computer Science or a related discipline. Previously having taken CSC486/2502 (or equivalent) with good results is strongly recommended.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Has taken an undergraduate/graduate compiler course equivalent to CSC488S. Experience in developing large programs (preferably compilers) in the Java programming language including use of ant and version control tools. Experience with modern compiler development tools like Lex/Flex/JFlex and YACC/Bison/CUP/JCup. Experience in marking large programming assignments. Ability to analyze and critique compiler design proposals. Ability to evaluate the quality of program testing and documentation.
duties: Marking of 5 stages of a compiler implementation project including programs, documentation and testing. Prepare and present tutorials on compiler related material.

qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Has taken an undergraduate/graduate compiler course equivalent to CSC488. Experience in developing large programs (preferably compilers) using Java and Python. Experience with modern compiler development tools like Lex/Flex/JFlex and YACC/Bison/CUP/JCup. Ability to analyze and critique compiler design proposals. Ability to evaluate the quality of program testing and documentation.
duties: Grading assignments and exams. Prepare and present tutorials on compiler related material.

qualifications: Demonstrated high-level research experience, technical prowess on a wide array of software & hardware development technologies.  Serious hacking chops. Real world experience developing software in a team environment. In addition to filling out this application form, interested applicants must contact the TA Coordinator Dr. Dan Zingaro <daniel.zingaro@utoronto.ca>.

course_name: Capstone Project: Business of Software Build Component
qualifications: Must be enrolled in, or have completed, an undergraduate program in Computer Science or a related field. Must have finished a PEY with a software company and worked in a team environment where prototyping and feature development was needed. Business skills and startup experience would be good to have.
duties: TA duties will include marking and Q&A Assignment info sessions.

qualifications: Demonstrated familiarity with standard algorithm design techniques (greedy strategies, dynamic programming, network flow and linear programming) and with the theory of NP-completeness. Experience marking proofs of correctness and complexity analysis of algorithms, as well as reductions for NP-completeness.
duties: TA duties may include marking, leading skills development tutorials, Q&A/Exam/Assignment/Test Review sessions, and laboratories where noted.

qualifications: TA experience in CS courses at UofT, evidence of excellent teaching skills, enthusiasm for teaching beginners, strong background in the relevant focus area (see Responsibilities), excellent communication skills in English (verbal and in writing), excellent interpersonal skills. As well as filling in the online application, applicants must submit additional information by email. See "Application Process" below. Duration: 54-108 hours (one-two "standard" TAships) from January - April, 2017. Work in the Help Centre will take place in the late afternoon to early evening, Mondays to Thursdays. There will be flexibility for picking times within that range, but applicants should generally be available at that time of day/week. Application process: 1) Fill out the regular online TA application at http://uoft.me/cs-ta-app, and 2) email helpcentretapp[at]cs.toronto.edu to arrange an interview with the Associate Chair, Francois Pitt. Include the following information in your email: evidence of satisfying each of the requirements above, and the name of at least one reference who can comment on your teaching ability.
duties: Each Help Centre TA will focus on one of the following areas: first-year (csc108, 148, and 165), theory courses (primarily 373), programming courses (primarily 209 and 324). Maintain some familiarity with the current assignments in key courses. Other related duties as required. Staff a Help Centre for undergraduate students, providing help to students on a drop-in basis.
